brief_summary.textblock:
Traumatic brain injury is common cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Incidence and
      pattern of traumatic brain injury varies in developed and developing countries. Subarachnoid
      haemorrhage refers to blood in subarachnoid space that lies between arachnoid and
      piameninges, covering brain.  It is often associated with concurrent intracranial injury
      component. Individuals at higher risk for tSAH are those who are at higher risk for blunt
      head trauma. This includes adolescents, low-income individuals, men, and individuals with a
      history of substance abuse. The investigators present study aims to investigate prognostic
      factors associated with the neurological outcome among patients of post traumatic SAH.

clinical_study.brief_title: Neurological Outcome in Patients of Traumatic Subarachnoid Haemorrhage

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  All patients of traumatic subarachnoid haemorrhage

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Metabolic disorder

          -  Altered coagulation profile

          -  Cardiac disease

          -  Co- morbid illness

clinical_study.official_title: Incidence and Outcomes of Traumatic Subarachnoid Haemorrhage Patients: A Cross Sectional Study

primary_outcome.measure: Level of consciousness measured by Glasgow coma scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to one month

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: appearance of subarachnoid hemorrhage on CT measured by Fisher Grading
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to one month
